parse.title: Gold Medal Award for Distinguished Archaeological Achievement

text.*:
This article relies too much on references to primary sources. Please improve this by adding secondary or tertiary sources. (January 2015) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)

The Gold Medal Award for Distinguished Archaeological Achievement is awarded by the Archaeological Institute of America in "recognition of a scholar who has made distinguished contributions to archaeology through his or her fieldwork, publications, and/or teaching."

It is the Institute's highest award. First awarded in 1965, it has been awarded annually since 1969.[1]

Contents

  • 1 List of AIA Gold Medal winners
  • 2 See also
  • 3 References
  • 4 External links

List of AIA Gold Medal winners[edit]

  • 2018:Ian Hodder, Stanford University
  • 2017:John R. Clarke, University of Texas at Austin[2]
  • 2016:Malcolm Bell III, University of Virginia[3]
  • 2015: Charles Brian Rose[4]
  • 2014: L. Hugh Sackett
  • 2013: Jeremy B. Rutter[5][6]
  • 2012: Lawrence Richardson Jr.
  • 2011: Susan Irene Rotroff[7]
  • 2010: John Humphrey[8]
  • 2009: Henry Tutwiler Wright[9]
  • 2008: James Wiseman[10][11]
  • 2007: Larissa Bonfante[12]
  • 2006: Maria C. Shaw and Joseph W. Shaw[13][14]
  • 2005: Lionel Casson[15][16]
  • 2004: David B. Stronach[17]
  • 2003: Philip Betancourt[18][19]
  • 2002: Robert McCormick Adams[20]
  • 2001: Emmett L. Bennett Jr.[21]
  • 1999: Patty Jo Watson[22][23]
  • 1998: Anna Marguerite McCann[24][25]
  • 1997: Clemency Chase Coggins[26][27]
  • 1996: Wilhelmina F. Jashemski[28][29]
  • 1995: R. Ross Holloway[30]
  • 1994: Emeline Richardson[31]
  • 1993: Charles Kaufman Williams, II[32]
  • 1992: Evelyn Byrd Harrison[33]
  • 1991: Machteld J. Mellink[34][35]
  • 1990: John W. Hayes[36]
  • 1989: Virginia R. Grace[37]
  • 1988: Brunilde Sismondo Ridgway[38] and John Desmond Clark[39][40]
  • 1987: Dorothy Burr Thompson[41]
  • 1986: George F. Bass[42][43][44]
  • 1985: Saul S. Weinberg and Gladys Davidson Weinberg[45]
  • 1984: Margaret Thompson[46]
  • 1983: James Bennet Pritchard[47]
  • 1982: Peter H. von Blanckenhagen
  • 1981: William Andrew McDonald[48]
  • 1980: John Langdon Caskey[49][50]
  • 1979: Dows Dunham[51][52]
  • 1978: George M.A. Hanfmann[53]
  • 1977: Lucy Shoe Meritt[54]
  • 1976: Edith Porada[55]
  • 1975: Eugene Vanderpool[56]
  • 1974: Margarete Bieber[57]
  • 1973: Gordon R. Willey[58]
  • 1972: Homer A. Thompson[59]
  • 1971: Robert John Braidwood[60]
  • 1970: George E. Mylonas[61]
  • 1969: Oscar Theodore Broneer, Rhys Carpenter, and William B. Dinsmoor Jr.
  • 1968: Gisela M. A. Richter[62]
  • 1967: William Foxwell Albright[63]
  • 1966: Hetty Goldman[64]
  • 1965: Carl W. Blegen[65]
